oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nance Bend School

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Flags; Flagpoles; Children; School children; Rural schools; One-room schools
Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-story white frame structure. A covered porch is on the left side of the building and an American flag flies next to it. A group of African American children stand outside; one has a baseball bat and another has a baseball glove. A school bell stands next to the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Education Schoolhouse Photos, 1938-1942
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nance Bend School was for African American children; grades 7 to 8. In 1938, Rebecca Fall was the principal and only teacher, and D. G. White was the county superintendent. Nineteen students were enrolled at the one-room schoolhouse. It scored 86 out of 100 points on its application for approved rural school.
